caption: Table 1: Comparison to previous kernel-based works on generator learning. Sample size is n, state-space dimension is d, y is the regularization parameter of KKR and RRR and r is RRR rank parameter. Our learning bounds are derived in Theorem 2 where the parameters α, β, τ quantify the intrinsic difficulty of the problem and impact of kernel choice on learning IG.
description: This table compares the proposed method with three other kernel-based methods for learning the infinitesimal generator (IG) of stochastic diffusion processes.  The comparison is made across several aspects: the range of SDEs covered, the type of risk metric used, whether the method incorporates physical priors, the ability to avoid spurious eigenvalues, the provided IG error bounds, spectral convergence rates, and time complexity.

caption: Table 1: Comparison to previous kernel-based works on generator learning. Sample size is n, state-space dimension is d, y is the regularization parameter of KKR and RRR and r is RRR rank parameter. Our learning bounds are derived in Theorem 2 where the parameters α, β, τ quantify the intrinsic difficulty of the problem and impact of kernel choice on learning IG.
description: This table compares the proposed method with previous kernel-based works on infinitesimal generator learning for stochastic diffusion processes.  It highlights key differences across several aspects, including the types of stochastic differential equations (SDEs) handled, the risk metrics used, whether the methods are physics-informed, whether spurious eigenvalues are avoided, the error bounds achieved, the spectral convergence rates, and the time complexity. The table also introduces parameters (α, β, τ) from Theorem 2 that characterize the intrinsic difficulty of learning the infinitesimal generator and how the choice of kernel affects this difficulty.
